contentrichtext.text: {{redirect3|Tsugumi|for the Japanese actress, see [[Tsugumi (actress)]]}} {{Taxobox | name = Dusky Thrush | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN2006|assessors=[[BirdLife International]]|year=2004|id=51604|title=Turdus naumanni|downloaded=12 May 2006}}</ref> | image = Turdus eunomus -Japan-8.jpg | image_caption=In Japan | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Passeriformes]] | familia = [[Turdidae]] | genus = ''[[Turdus]]'' | species = '''''T. eunomus''''' | binomial = ''Turdus eunomus'' | binomial_authority = [[Coenraad Jacob Temminck|Temminck]], 1820 }} The '''Dusky Thrush''' (''Turdus eunomus'') is a member of the [[Thrush (bird)|thrush]] family Turdidae which breeds eastwards from central [[Siberia]]. It is closely related to the more southerly breeding [[Naumann's Thrush]] ''T. naumanni''; the two have often been regarded as [[conspecific]]. This species breeds in open woodland areas, but unlike Naumann's Thrush, Dusky Thrush is more tolerant of mountainous and tundra-edge habitats. This species is strongly [[bird migration|migratory]], wintering south to southeast [[Asia]], principally in [[China]] and neighbouring countries. It is a rare vagrant to western [[Europe]]. It nests in trees, laying 3-5 [[Egg (biology)|egg]]s in an untidy but neatly lined nest. Migrating birds and wintering birds often form small flocks. It is omnivorous, eating a wide range of [[insects]], especially [[mosquito]]es, [[earthworm]]s and berries. This is a medium-sized but stocky thrush, reminiscent in structure of a small [[Fieldfare]]. The underwing is reddish brown, and there is a pale [[wikt:Supercilium|supercilium]]. Dusky Thrush has a dark brown back and rump; the face, breast, and flank spots rump are black and the belly and undertail are white. Naumann's Thrush in comparison has a paler brown back and head; the face, breast, flank spots and rump are reddish, and the belly and undertail are white. The female is fairly similar to the male, but immatures have a weaker patterning. The male Dusky Thrush has a simple fluted or whistling song, similar to the [[Redwing]]. There are suggestions that the songs of Dusky and Naumann's Thrush differ. == References ==<!-- FaunAbh26:63. FieldMusNatHistZoolSer18:343. Forktail16:147. --> {{reflist}} == Bibliography == * ''Thrushes'', Clement and Hathway, ISBN 0-7136-3940-7 == External links == * {{Cite web |url=http://www.itis.gov/servlet/SingleRpt/SingleRpt?search_topic=TSN&search_value=179756 |title=''Turdus naumanni'' Temminck, 1820 |publisher=[[ITIS]] |accessdate=2012-02-28}} {{wikispecies|Turdus eunomus}} {{commons|Turdus eunomus}} [[Category:Turdus]] [[Category:Birds of Nepal]] [[Category:Birds of Pakistan]] [[Category:Birds of India]] [[Category:Animals described in 1820]]
